Join the conversation and make your voice heard!

Senior Spotlight: Willow Schaefer

My dear Willow,
You are a bright star in this cluster of luminous classmates. Your trajectory has moved throughout our community, your path marked by creativity, sensitivity and perseverance. I remember so clearly the video game you created in sixth grade, when allowed your own choice for an assignment. That ability to surprise and challenge those around you has continued through the years, as you finish your first year at Northern University. I have always appreciated your openness, your willingness to share your warm and expansive heart. I saw quickly how your fierce love for family and friends shaped your daily life, and how your drive to improve yourself included an invitation for others to rise with you. Whether it was forensics, music, soccer, Tae kwon Do, academics, you offered an open hand. You continue to amaze me, my dear Willow, as you move into a new trajectory of life.
You have my respect and best wishes, and as always, my love.
Mrs. Janet Beegle Gay

Senior Spotlight: Kevin Ricker

Kevin,
It took awhile for you to open up and let me get to know you, but when you did I was impressed by your thoughts and the connections you made from the information you learned. Your ability to be a friend to anyone who needs one is what the world needs, so the world is blessed to have you in it. Mr. Emerson told me a tale about you once and it sticks with me because it rings true, but is also not the person I saw when we spoke. It shows that you have grown tremendously over the years to earn an impressive ability for control over yourself, your actions, your thoughts, and your abilities. The tale was of a basketball game in which the opposing team was being unsportsmanlike. He said that your coach had you benched at the time and when it became clear the opposing coach was going to continue the behavior your coach warned, ‚ÄúHey coach, if you keep this up I‚Äôm going to put Ricker in.‚Äù And that was all it took. You are a ‚ÄúJohn Wick‚Äù kind of man who will avenge the death of your dog, because it wasn‚Äôt ‚Äújust a dog‚Äù.
Mrs. Reeve

Senior Spotlight: Davis Parker

Dear Davis,

If a good life is one that is characterized by complete absorption in what one does (Nakamura and Csikzentmihalyi), then Davis Parker, you are sure to find great happiness in the years to come (as long as you go easy on the strawberry shortcake). With your easy-going, good-natured ways, you experienced and worked hard at all that BMU had to offer. From 2nd grade bat boy on the DIV championship baseball team, to a lead role in the musical Annie Jr., and from Middle School Scholar and trumpet player to point guard on the varsity basketball team, your humility and friendship were noticed and appreciated by all. But it is your passion for the world of S.T.E.M., your work with Robotics, and CRREL, and your dual enrollment at Vermont Tech that gives us inspiration. Your passion for engineering inspires us to look at life with curiosity and interest. What an amazing role model you have been. George, we‚Äôre really going to miss you.

Mrs. Burns (AKA-Trista)

Senior Spotlight: Joshua Ottoni

Josh,
You are more self aware than many people twice your age, yet I do not think you realize that about yourself. You know what you want and what you need; more importantly, you know the steps you need to make to earn those things. You plan and you prepare and you have fun. You show determination and perseverance in the projects you take on. Your willingness to help others who are struggling or are in need is inspiring, Casually stating my shift pedal was not compatible with my boot size, you jumped onto your phone to suss out a solution that did not require buying new boots. Your leadership qualities are visible by all. Use that power knowing it comes with great responsibility (as Uncle Ben said to Peter Parker). Use your many strengths to benefit yourself and your community; enjoy your years of independence.
Good luck in the stock market and your get rich quick schemes.
Mrs. Reeve

Senior Spotlight: Caitlyn Loud

Dear Caitlyn,
Wow. You decide to leave homeschooling and return to the hallways and classrooms of BMU, and then Covid 19 happens and you are back home on your computer! Thank goodness we had you here for a few months! I can‚Äôt imagine class without your insightful, sometimes sarcastic, but always intriguing comments. I can‚Äôt imagine senior hall without your calm, kind support of your classmates. I can‚Äôt imagine not seeing your smile each day or hearing your bemused chuckle as you watch the world go by. You are a model of exemplary academic scholarship, self-advocacy, and that elusive quality called ‚Äúgrit.‚Äù You are not afraid to work hard to achieve YOUR goals, and not just react to the expectations of others. Because of your world travels, you have brought new, valuable viewpoints to our class community. I am so glad that you decided to wander into my classroom this year!
Best wishes for your journeys ahead,
Mrs. Kane

Any player born prior to May 1, 2007 and on or after May 1, 2004 will be eligible for Babe Ruth 13-15 League competition.

All players born in 2003 or through 2006.

It is with sadness that we announce to the BMU community that Mrs. Trudy Fadden (our former BMU middle school Science teacher) passed away yesterday morning. Mrs. Fadden had been dealing with a very aggressive form of cancer. She fought a hard battle, but, the cancer was too aggressive and over took her body. Mrs. Fadden did not want information about her illness made public. She was a very private person and out of respect to her and to her family, we honored her request.

Counselors are available here at BMU for students and staff who need someone to speak with. They are here to help.

Once we have more information about services for Mrs. Fadden, and based upon input from the family, we will share the information.

BMU sends our heart felt condolences to Mrs. Fadden's family, friends, colleagues and former students.

VT Div. IV Basketball Championship Game

post_text:
Humans in Buck Territory

"Being a senior, and knowing that this is my last chance to win a championship, is nerve wracking. This final game is something I know I have to put it all out on the court for. After losing last year, we knew we had to come back stronger. Getting the chance to play MSJ, who beat us in the championship last season and beating them in the semifinals, was definitely one of the best accomplishments of this season. Now, getting the chance to play West Rutland and win a State championship is absolutely amazing!" ~ Mika White
